{{Expand German|50Hertz Transmission|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = 50Hertz Transmission GmbH | logo = 50Hertz Logo.svg | caption = | type = | traded_as = | fate = | predecessor = Vattenfall Europe Transmission
Verbundnetz Elektroenergie | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|2002}} | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Berlin]] | location_country = Germany | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = * Boris Schucht (CEO) * Dr. Frank Golletz (CTO) * Marco Nix (CFO) * Dr. Dirk Biermann (CMO) | industry = [[Electricity]] | products = | services = [[Electric power transmission]] | revenue = {{euro|9.9 billion}} (2017){{cite web|title=50Hertz Annual Report 2017 |url=https://csr.50hertz.com/Portals/7/Content/50Hertz_Jahresbericht_2017_EN.pdf|website=50hertz.com|publisher=50 Hz Transmission|accessdate=2018-06-05}} | operating_income = | net_income = {{euro|182 million}} (2017) | assets = | equity = | owner = [[Elia System Operator]] (80%)
[[KfW]] (20%) | num_employees = 1.043 | parent = Eurogrid GmbH | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|www.50hertz.com/en/}} | footnotes = | intl = }} [[File:Regelzonen mit Übertragungsnetzbetreiber in Deutschland.png|thumb|200px|Map of transmission system operators in Germany]] '''50Hertz Transmission GmbH''' (former name: '''Vattenfall Europe Transmission''') is one of the four [[transmission system operator]]s for electricity in [[Germany]]. It is a member of the [[European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity]] (ENTSO-E). It is wholly owned by Eurogrid GmbH, indirectly owned and managed by the Belgian transmission system operator [[Elia System Operator]] and Australian-based [[IFM Investors]]. The company has headquarters in Berlin and owns the high power network in eastern Germany as well as the area around [[Hamburg]]. It operates the 220kV and 380kV networks and has about 10,200 km of power lines covering about 30% of Germany by area. The company employs 1.043 employees. On 12 March 2010, Elia System Operator and Industry Funds Management acquired 50Hertz Transmission from [[Vattenfall]]. The deal was approved by the [[European Commission]] on 10 May 2010. {{cite news | url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKBRQ00983320100510| title= Elia's buy of Vattenfall's German grid cleared by EU | author = Foo Yun Chee | agency = [[Reuters]] | date=2010-05-10 | accessdate=2010-06-28}} On 23 March 2018, Elia announced it has decided to exercise its pre-emption right and to increase its share in Eurogrid, the holding company above 50Hertz, from 60% to 80%. The transaction price amounts to € 976.5 million.{{cite web|title=Elia Press Release |url=https://www.eliagroup.eu/News/Detail/id/4667/elia-has-decided-to-acquire-an-additional-20-stake-in-german-transmission-system-operator-50hertz|website=eliagroup.eu|publisher=Elia Group|accessdate=2018-06-05}} Later that year, Elia announced the closing of the transactions with IFM and the German state-owned bank Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau ([[KfW]]) regarding a 20% stake in Eurogrid International. With the close of these transactions, KfW, on behalf of the German Federal Government, replaces IFM as shareholder in Eurogrid.Press release (August 22, 2018), [http://www.eliagroup.eu/News/Detail/id/5816/elia-welcomes-german-bank-kfw-as-shareholder-in-transmission-system-operator-50hertz GElia welcomes German Bank KfW as shareholder in transmission system operator 50Hertz] ''[[Elia System Operator|Elia]]''. == Business Activities == {{Empty section|date=November 2014}} == See also == {{Portal|Germany|Energy|Companies}} * [[Amprion GmbH]] * [[TenneT]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website}} {{Vattenfall}} {{European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[Category:Electric power transmission system operators in Germany]] [[Category:Vattenfall]] {{Germany-company-stub}} {{energy-company-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use British English|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox aircraft occurrence |name=Airship NS11 crash |image=ModelofNorthSeaAirship.jpg |caption= A model of an NS class airship similar to NS11 |coordinates = |Date= {{Start date|1919|07|15|df=y}} |Type= [[Lightning strike]] (suspected) |occurrence_type=Accident |Site= [[North Sea]] off [[Cley next the Sea]], [[Norfolk]], [[England]] |Coordinates = {{coord|52.951|1.043|display=inline,title}} |Fatalities= 9 |Injuries=0 |Aircraft Type= [[NS class airship]] |aircraft_name= |Operator= [[Royal Air Force]] |Tail Number= NS11 |plane1_origin = [[RAF Pulham]] |Destination = [[RAF Pulham]] |Crew= 9 |Survivors=0 }}
The '''Airship ''NS11'' crash''' was an [[airship]] accident which occurred on 15 July 1919. The [[Royal Air Force]] (RAF) airship exploded off the east coast of [[England]] over the [[North Sea]], killing all nine crew on board.
==Aircraft== ''NS11'' was one of 14 [[NS class airship|''North Sea''-class]] airships ordered by the Royal Navy for the [[Royal Naval Air Service]], but by the time ''NS11'' was delivered in September 1918, the Royal Naval Air Service had been amalgamated with the [[Royal Flying Corps]] to form the RAF. The airship was built and tested at [[RNAS Kingsnorth]] near [[Kingsnorth (Medway)|Kingsnorth]] in [[Kent]]. She was fitted with two 260 hp (195 kW) [[Fiat]] engines and had an [[Airship#Envelope|envelope]] with a capacity of {{convert|360000|ft3|m3|abbr=on}} cubic feet. Prior to the accident, she had made voyages of more than 1000 miles (1600 km) over the North Sea, setting a world record for non-rigid airships.<ref name="NYT19190716p1">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1919/07/16/archives/british-airship-burns-with-crew-twelve-lost-when-the-ns11-falls.html|title=British Airship Burns with Crew; Twelve Lost When the NS-11 Falls Flaming Into the North Sea|publisher= The New York Times|date= 16 July 1919|accessdate= 29 October 2013}}</ref>
==Accident== ''NS11'' had taken off from [[RAF Pulham]] in [[Pulham St Mary]], [[Norfolk]], around midnight on the night of 14/15 July 1919 and was heading over the [[North Sea]] on a [[Minehunter|mine-hunting patrol]].<ref name="NYT19190716p1" /><ref name="times" /><ref name="NS11 - Local View">{{cite web|url= http://www.ns11.org/loss-of-ns11-%E2%80%93-a-local-view/|title= NS11 - A Local View|accessdate= 29 October 2013|publisher= ns11.org}}</ref> In the early hours of 15 July, she was seen to fly beneath a long "greasy black cloud" off the village of [[Cley next the Sea]] on the Norfolk coast when locals reported an abnormal noise from her engines (which may have suggested she was experiencing engine trouble).<ref name="NYT19190716p1" /> She was returning towards the coast when she exploded into a ball of flames, causing a vivid glare lasting for several minutes as the burning airship descended, plunging into the sea after a second explosion. None of the nine crew members on board the airship survived.<ref name="NYT19190716p1" /><ref name="NS11 - As Bright as Day">{{cite web|url= http://www.ns11.org|title= NS11 - As Bright as Day|accessdate= 29 October 2013|publisher= ns11.org}}</ref> The [[Sheringham Lifeboat Station|Sheringham lifeboat]] was launched but its crew could only find a small part of the aluminium wreckage.<ref name="times">"Airship Burnt At Sea." Times [London, England] 16 July 1919: 12. The Times Digital Archive. Web. 29 Oct. 2013</ref>
The accident occurred less than 48 hours after the airship ''[[R33-class airship|R34]]'' arrived at RAF Pulham after a successful double-crossing of the Atlantic Ocean, including the first-ever east-west crossing by air.
==Cause== The findings of the official Court of Enquiry were inconclusive, but amongst other possibilities it was thought that a lightning strike may have caused the explosion.<ref name="NS11 - Local View" />
==Aftermath== There is a memorial plaque and drinking fountain in the grounds of the Viaduct Sports & Social Club in [[Earlestown]], [[Merseyside]]. The names of the crew are commemorated on Hollybrook Memorial, [[Southampton]]. One of the crew was buried at Ann’s Hill Cemetery in [[Gosport]].<ref name="NS11 - Memorials">{{cite web|url= http://www.ns11.org/the-last-crew/memorials/|title= NS11 - Memorials|accessdate= 29 October 2013|publisher=ns11.org}}</ref>
==See also== * [[R38-class airship]] * [[R101]] * [[List of airship accidents]] * [[History of the Royal Navy]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Aviation accidents and incidents before 1920}}
